isis.stitle: VT 275 Engine Diagnostics Manual - Engine Symptoms Diagnostics - Test Procedures - Coolant Leak to Exhaust

svcsubproc.title: Coolant Leak to Exhaust Test Procedure

step1.para: Verify complaint of coolant leaking to exhaust.

item.para: Observation of coolant loss without engine overheating
Excessive white smoke from exhaust pipe on start up (hot or cold)
Check for coolant smell in exhaust
Check for coolant leaking from muffler

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death, comply with the following:

item.para: Use caution when removing turbocharger exhaust tubing, coolant in tubing could splash or create slippery conditions.
Allow engine to cool before removing any components.

Do not allow engine fluids to stay on your skin. Clean skin and nails with soap and water, or a good hand cleaner. Wash or properly dispose of clothing or rags containing engine fluids. Engine fluids contain elements that may be unhealthy for skin and could cause cancer.

note.para: Engine fluids, oil, fuel, and coolant, are a threat to the environment. Recycle or dispose of engine fluids according to local regulations. Never put engine fluids in the trash, on the ground, in sewers or other bodies of water.

step1.para: Remove turbocharger to exhaust muffler tubing and the exhaust tube to EGR cooler following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
Check for presence of coolant in tubing, exhaust manifolds and EGR cooler exhaust inlet.
Plug in the cylinder block heater, if available, to warm coolant.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death from hot coolant or steam scalding, use the following procedure to remove the pressure cap from the cooling system. Allow the engine to cool. Wrap a thick cloth around the cap. Unscrew cap slowly, then pause to allow pressure to release.

step1.para: Follow procedure in the above warning to remove cooling system pressure cap.
Pressurize cooling system to 96 kPa (14 psi) using the radiator pressure tester.
Check EGR cooler exhaust inlet for the presence of coolant.

item.para: If coolant is present, replace EGR cooler following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If no leak is found but pressure is dropping rapidly, inspect the exhaust manifolds for coolant. Repair as necessary following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If no leak is found, continue with step 8.

step1.para: Remove EGR valve and install Intake Manifold Pressure Test Plug (EGR Valve) (ZTSE4544) and EGR Cooler Test Plate (ZTSE4545) on the EGR cooler following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
Remove radiator pressure tester from coolant deaeration tank and fill tank with coolant to a point above the deaeration inlet line to tank. Leave radiator cap off.

figure.caption: EGR Cooler Test Plate, air regulator and test gauge installed
Intake Manifold Pressure Test Plug (EGR Valve) installed

step1.para: Apply regulated air pressure of 172 to 414 kPa (25 to 60 psi) at the EGR Cooler Pressure Test Plate.
Observe coolant deaeration tank for air bubbles. Air pressure must be left on EGR cooler for a minimum of 5 minutes.

item.para: If air bubbles are observed in the tank, remove EGR cooler and retest following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual to verify EGR cooler is inoperative. Replace if necessary.
If air bubbles are observed and EGR cooler passes additional testing, remove and pressure test the intake manifold following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If no air bubbles are observed or EGR cooler and intake manifold have passed testing, contact Technical Services for further assistance.
